title: Writing Independent Equations for Water and Sugar
text: Since the water increases at $$10$$ gallons per minute, and the sugar increases at $$1$$ pound per minute, these are constant rates of change. This tells us the amount of water in the tank is changing linearly, as is the amount of sugar in the tank.

hintAnswer: water: $$W(t)=100+10t$$ in gallons, sugar: $$S(t)=5+1t$$ in pounds
title: Select Independent Equations
text: Which pair of equations best represents the equations for water and sugar? Let $$t$$ be the number of minutes since the tap opened.
choices: water: $$W(t)=100+10t$$ in gallons, sugar: $$S(t)=5+1t$$ in pounds
water: $$W(t)=5+1t$$ in gallons, sugar: $$S(t)=100+10t$$ in pounds
water: $$W(t)=100+1t^2$$ in gallons, sugar: $$S(t)=5t^2$$ in pounds

title: Concentration
text: The concentration will be the ratio of pounds of sugar to gallons of water. Think about how you can represent that ratio from the equations for water and sugar.

title: Find the Concentration in the Beginning
Compare the concentrations
text: Is the concentration after $$12$$ mins greater, less, or the same as the concentration in the beginning?
